q7.question: Which of the following statements is true about the MLFQ scheduling policy (choose all that apply)?

responses.queues: MLFQ uses multiple queues with different priority levels.
responses.apriori: MLFQ requires a priori knowledge of the processes.
responses.roundrobin: MLFQ uses round-robin to schedule jobs of the same priority level.
responses.raises: MLFQ raises the priority of a job that has used up its entire time slice.
responses.lowers: MLFQ lowers the priority of a job once it uses up its allotment at a given level.
responses.sjf: MLFQ approximates SJF because it assumes jobs are short and starts them with the highest priority.
responses.starvation: MLFQ overcomes the problem of starvation by periodically performing a priority boost.

q8.question: Which of the following statements is true about the proportional-share scheduling policy (choose all that apply)?

responses.tickets: Tickets represent the share of a resource a process should receive.
responses.random: The use of randomness is advantageous since it avoids worst case scenarios, is lightweight, and fast.
responses.transfer: Once allocated, a process has a constant number of tickets.
responses.guarantee: Proportional-share scheduling guarantees meeting desired division of work.
responses.implementation: This policy is simple to implement with a random number generator and a linked list that tracks the processes.
